text: If we allow people to eat chocolate every day, soon everyone will be eating nothing but chocolate and become unhealthy.
corrected: Allowing people to eat chocolate every day does not mean they will stop eating other foods or become unhealthy, as moderation and balanced diets are still possible.

text: You shouldn't vote for him; he's been divorced twice!
corrected: A person's marital history does not necessarily reflect their ability to govern; policies and qualifications should be evaluated instead.

text: Everyone is buying this new phone, so it must be the best.
corrected: Popularity does not determine quality; the phone should be evaluated based on its features and performance.

text: If we legalize marijuana, next we'll legalize all drugs, and society will collapse.
corrected: Legalizing marijuana does not inevitably lead to legalizing all drugs; policies can be implemented with regulation.

text: All scientists agree that climate change is real, so it must be true.
corrected: While consensus among scientists is strong, claims should be supported by evidence rather than just authority.

text: You either support the war, or you hate your country.
corrected: There are more nuanced positions; one can oppose a war while still loving their country.

text: This medicine works because it's natural.
corrected: Natural does not always mean safe or effective; scientific evidence should determine efficacy.

text: She's a great singer because she says she's the best.
corrected: Her claim of being the best does not prove her skill; evidence like vocal ability should be assessed.

text: We should ban all violent video games because one criminal played them.
corrected: A single case does not prove causation; broader research is needed to assess effects.

text: If you don’t donate to our charity, you don’t care about children.
corrected: Not donating does not imply indifference; people may support causes in different ways.

text: My grandfather smoked every day and lived to 100, so smoking isn’t harmful.
corrected: A single case does not override statistical evidence showing smoking's health risks.

text: The president raised taxes, and then the economy crashed—clearly, taxes caused it.
corrected: Correlation does not prove causation; other economic factors likely contributed.

text: You can't criticize the government; it's unpatriotic!
corrected: Constructive criticism is part of a healthy democracy, not necessarily unpatriotic.

text: This diet pill works—just look at this celebrity who lost weight!
corrected: A single success story does not prove effectiveness; clinical studies are needed.

text: If you don’t believe in my religion, you’ll go to hell.
corrected: Belief should be based on reasoned argument, not fear of punishment.

text: We shouldn’t change the law because it’s always been this way.
corrected: Tradition alone is not a valid reason to keep a law; current relevance should be considered.

text: You’re wrong because you’re too young to understand.
corrected: Age does not determine correctness; arguments should be evaluated on merit.

text: All rich people are greedy.
corrected: Wealth does not determine character; individuals should be judged separately.

text: If we let students redo tests, soon nobody will study!
corrected: Redoing tests does not necessarily lead to no studying; students may still prepare.

text: This politician is corrupt because my opponent says so.
corrected: Claims should be backed by evidence, not just an opponent’s accusation.

text: You can’t trust her opinion; she’s a known liberal.
corrected: Her political leaning does not automatically invalidate her argument.

text: The Bible is true because it says it’s the word of God.
corrected: A text cannot prove its own validity; external evidence is needed.

text: If we allow gay marriage, next people will marry animals!
corrected: Legalizing same-sex marriage does not logically lead to bestiality; they are unrelated.

text: He must be guilty; he looks suspicious.
corrected: Guilt must be proven with evidence, not assumptions based on looks.

text: You should buy this car; real men drive trucks.
corrected: Vehicle choice does not determine masculinity; preferences vary.

text: Four out of five dentists recommend this toothpaste!
corrected: The sample may be biased; how many dentists were surveyed?

text: If you don’t support my business, you’re not a true friend.
corrected: Friendship should not be conditional on business support.

text: She’s a bad leader because she’s too emotional.
corrected: Leadership should be judged by results, not stereotypes about emotions.

text: This law is bad because a criminal supports it.
corrected: A law’s merit depends on its content, not who supports it.

text: You can’t be tired; you’re just lazy!
corrected: Tiredness and laziness are different; fatigue may have legitimate causes.

text: We should ignore climate change; winters are still cold!
corrected: Local weather does not refute global climate trends.

text: If you don’t agree with me, you must be stupid.
corrected: Disagreement does not indicate intelligence; differing perspectives exist.

text: This policy is good because it’s patriotic!
corrected: Patriotism does not automatically make a policy effective or just.

text: He's a great athlete, so he must be a great person too.
corrected: Athletic skill does not necessarily reflect moral character.

text: You're either with us, or against us.
corrected: Neutral or nuanced positions may exist beyond binary choices.

text: She failed the test, so she must not have studied.
corrected: Other factors (illness, misunderstanding) could explain the result.

text: This movie is terrible because the critics hated it.
corrected: Personal taste may differ; the movie should be judged on its own merits.

text: If we teach evolution, students will stop believing in God!
corrected: Learning science does not necessarily negate religious faith.

text: He’s a criminal, so his opinion on laws is worthless.
corrected: Past crimes do not automatically invalidate his arguments.

text: This product is expensive, so it must be high-quality.
corrected: Price does not always correlate with quality; evidence is needed.

text: You don’t support tax cuts? You must love big government!
corrected: Opposing tax cuts does not necessarily mean supporting big government.

text: She’s a scientist, so she must be an atheist.
corrected: Scientists hold diverse religious views; profession does not dictate belief.

text: If we let refugees in, crime will skyrocket!
corrected: Refugees are not inherently criminals; data should be examined.

text: You can’t trust his research; he’s funded by a corporation.
corrected: Funding source does not automatically invalidate findings, but transparency helps.

text: This law is unjust because it’s unpopular.
corrected: Justice should be based on principles, not just public opinion.

text: If you don’t eat organic, you’re poisoning yourself.
corrected: Non-organic food is not inherently poisonous; risks vary.

text: He’s a great speaker, so his policies must be good.
corrected: Charisma does not equal sound policy; ideas should be evaluated separately.

text: We’ve always used coal, so we shouldn’t switch to renewables.
corrected: Past practices should not prevent progress if better options exist.

text: You’re wrong because you’re not an expert.
corrected: Non-experts can still make valid points; arguments should stand on their own.

text: If we allow free speech, hate speech will take over!
corrected: Free speech can coexist with limits without leading to chaos.

text: This policy worked in Sweden, so it will work here.
corrected: Different countries have unique contexts; results may vary.

text: She’s a bad mom because she works full-time.
corrected: Parenting quality is not determined solely by employment status.

text: You don’t like this band? You must have terrible taste!
corrected: Musical preference is subjective; disagreement is not a personal flaw.

text: If we ban guns, only criminals will have them!
corrected: Regulation does not necessarily lead to total disarmament of law-abiding citizens.

text: This politician is honest because he says so.
corrected: Self-claim does not prove honesty; actions and evidence do.

text: You can’t be a feminist if you wear makeup.
corrected: Feminism allows for personal choice, including makeup.

text: If you don’t support the military, you’re un-American.
corrected: Patriotism can take many forms, including questioning policies.

text: He’s a genius, so he must be right about everything.
corrected: Intelligence does not guarantee infallibility.

text: This medicine is natural, so it’s safe.
corrected: Natural substances can still be harmful; safety requires testing.

text: You’re too poor to understand economics.
corrected: Financial status does not determine understanding of economic principles.

text: If you don’t like this movie, you hate art.
corrected: Disliking one film does not equate to rejecting all art.

text: This diet worked for me, so it will work for everyone!
corrected: Individual results vary; broader studies are needed.

text: The CEO is rich, so he must be greedy.
corrected: Wealth does not automatically imply greed; individual actions matter.

text: If we let kids choose their bedtime, they’ll never sleep!
corrected: Children can learn responsibility without extreme outcomes.

text: You’re not a real vegan if you sometimes eat honey.
corrected: Veganism has varying interpretations; purity tests are subjective.

text: This law is good because it’s new.
corrected: Newness does not guarantee quality; the law’s merits should be evaluated.

text: You can’t criticize the military; they protect us!
corrected: Constructive criticism can coexist with respect for service.

text: If you support taxes, you must love wasting money.
corrected: Taxation funds public services; support does not imply waste.

text: She’s a lawyer, so she must be dishonest.
corrected: Profession does not determine character; individuals vary.

text: This policy failed before, so it will always fail.
corrected: Context changes over time; past failure does not guarantee future results.

text: You’re wrong because you’re not from here.
corrected: Origin does not invalidate arguments; evidence does.

text: If we teach sex ed, teens will become promiscuous!
corrected: Education does not necessarily increase risky behavior; it can promote safety.

text: He’s a celebrity, so his opinion on politics matters.
corrected: Fame does not equal expertise in governance.

text: You’re either part of the solution or part of the problem.
corrected: Neutral or mixed roles exist; issues are rarely binary.

text: This book is bad because the author is controversial.
corrected: Content should be judged separately from the author’s reputation.

text: If we let AI write articles, soon robots will replace all writers!
corrected: AI tools can assist without completely replacing human creativity.

text: You don’t exercise? You must be lazy.
corrected: Many factors (health, time) can affect exercise habits.

text: This politician is old, so he’s out of touch.
corrected: Age does not necessarily correlate with awareness; policies matter more.

text: If you don’t like capitalism, you must be a communist.
corrected: Economic views exist on a spectrum, not just two extremes.

text: This restaurant is always empty, so the food must be bad.
corrected: Other factors (location, marketing) could explain low patronage.

text: You’re not a real fan if you haven’t seen every episode.
corrected: Fandom is subjective; dedication varies.

text: If we allow protests, anarchy will follow!
corrected: Peaceful protests are a democratic right and do not guarantee chaos.

text: He’s a doctor, so he must be rich.
corrected: Doctors’ incomes vary; profession does not guarantee wealth.

text: This idea is stupid because nobody supports it.
corrected: Popularity does not determine validity; arguments should stand on merit.

text: If you don’t vote for me, the country will collapse!
corrected: Political outcomes are complex; no single election guarantees ruin.

text: You’re a vegetarian? You must hate farmers.
corrected: Vegetarianism is a dietary choice, not an attack on farmers.

text: This software is open-source, so it must be better.
corrected: Open-source has pros and cons; quality depends on implementation.

text: If we raise wages, all businesses will shut down!
corrected: Moderate wage increases can coexist with a healthy economy.

text: You’re not a real artist if you use digital tools.
corrected: Artistic mediums evolve; digital work is still valid art.

text: He’s a war hero, so his policies must be good.
corrected: Military service does not automatically make policies sound.

text: If we ban plastic straws, soon the government will control everything!
corrected: Environmental regulations do not necessarily lead to totalitarianism.

text: You’re a journalist, so you must be biased.
corrected: Journalists strive for objectivity; bias varies by individual.

text: This vaccine is new, so it must be unsafe.
corrected: Newness does not equal danger; testing determines safety.

text: If you don’t like my cooking, you’re ungrateful.
corrected: Personal taste is subjective; dislike does not imply ingratitude.

text: You’re a programmer, so you must be bad at social skills.
corrected: Profession does not dictate personality traits.

text: If we let kids play video games, they’ll never go outside!
corrected: Moderation is possible; gaming does not eliminate outdoor activity.

text: You’re not a real man if you cry.
corrected: Emotional expression is human, not gender-specific.

text: This politician is young, so he’s naive.
corrected: Age does not determine wisdom; ideas should be evaluated fairly.

text: If we allow this protest, soon riots will happen!

text: You’re a teacher, so you must love all children.
corrected: Teachers are individuals with varying patience and preferences.

text: This product is popular on TikTok, so it must be good.
corrected: Social media trends do not guarantee quality.

text: If you don’t support this law, you’re supporting criminals!
corrected: Opposition to a law can stem from various concerns, not just criminal sympathy.

text: You’re a banker, so you must be greedy.
corrected: Profession does not determine moral character.

text: If we don’t stop immigration, our culture will disappear!

text: You’re not a real gamer if you play on easy mode.
corrected: Gaming preferences vary; difficulty choice does not define fandom.

text: This policy is bad because a dictator once supported it.
corrected: A policy’s merit depends on its content, not past supporters.

text: If you don’t like dogs, you’re a bad person.
corrected: Personal preferences do not determine moral worth.

text: You’re a politician, so you must be corrupt.
corrected: Corruption varies by individual; profession does not dictate ethics.

text: If we allow free college, no one will value education!
corrected: Accessibility does not diminish value; many may pursue more learning.

text: You’re not a real athlete if you don’t play team sports.
corrected: Athleticism includes individual sports and diverse activities.

text: This theory is true because it can’t be disproven.
corrected: A claim requires positive evidence, not just lack of disproof.

text: If you don’t like this music, you have no soul.
